author: CC4
title: Direct Atomic Writes - No Staging, No Gatekeeping
core_argument: Trust the Agent, Simplify the System

reasoning_points.point: Staging creates coordination overhead that negates parallelism gains
reasoning_points.detail: 9.86x speedup proven. Position A serializes write path - parent waits, reads N branches, resolves, commits. Bottleneck moved.

reasoning_points.point: Atomic commits are already conflict-free by design
reasoning_points.detail: Each sub-agent writes about its own work. Different agents = different content domains. Contradictory facts are valuable signal.

reasoning_points.point: Parent gatekeeping = single point of failure
reasoning_points.detail: Parent crashes after children but before consolidation? Position A loses all child work. Position B already committed.
6 branches exist. Per-agent-per-run staging creates branch explosion. Git antipattern.
Direct writes: memories appear live. Staging: nothing until consolidation. Immediacy is a feature.

concessions: Nightly consolidation into sediment summaries is useful (post-hoc, not write-time)
Conflict detection matters - handle at read time, not write time
50+ agents may need rate limiting (throttling, not architecture)
challenges_to_position_a: What's consolidation latency budget? 30s kills speedup.
How handle parent failure? Orphaned staging = cleanup debt.
What conflict has actually occurred? Zero in experiments.
How does staging work at depth 3+? N levels of gatekeeping?
conclusion: Position A optimizes for write correctness. Position B optimizes for simplicity and speed. In memory systems, speed wins. Late memories can't inform the next action.
outcome: CW conceded staging branches and parent gatekeeping in Round 3. Debate converging on hybrid: direct writes + lineage tagging + async consolidation.
